awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Transforming Personalized Computing with Flexible Systems-On-Polymer
awd_abstract_narration:
Flexible electronics technology has the potential to transform computing by enabling bendable and stretchable systems at a low cost. Physical flexibility combined with cost and weight advantages opens a wide range of application areas, including wearable electronics, medical sensing and rollable displays. However, the performance and capabilities of purely flexible electronics are currently much more limited than the silicon technology. Emerging flexible hybrid electronics (FHE) integrates rigid silicon chips and printed electronics to bridge the gap between today's complex systems and flexible electronics. Hence, FHE can drive the next big leap forward in the form factor design, similar to the shift from desktop and laptop computers to hand-held devices. FHE systems differ significantly from traditional computing systems. First, physical flexibility and stretchability expands the design space into an uncharted dimension, which introduces intricate trade-offs with the traditional power, performance and area metrics. Second, bending and stretching can alter the characteristics of FHE systems. Finally, large batteries and heat sinks are prohibitive due to flexibility and wearability constraints. Therefore, there is a need for theoretically grounded and practically applicable tools that quantify physical flexibility as a new metric. The proposed project will advance the state-of-the-art in FHE by developing modeling, flexibility-aware optimization and run-time management techniques. 

FHE can be an enabler for ubiquitous devices for wearable computing, internet-of-things, body sensors, and medical applications. This project will help in transforming lives by providing a systematic approach to design wearable systems and arbitrarily shaped objects. For example, FHE can enable electronic patches equipped with motion, physiological and biochemical sensors, and wireless transceivers. These patches can be used to examine movement disorders anytime and anywhere, in stark contrast to the current practice, where a patient has to stay in a clinical environment. The educational goal of this project is to enrich the engineering curriculum with FHE. A digest of research outcomes will be presented to undergraduate and graduate students through a new course. This project will also provide hands-on training to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to strengthen the STEM workforce pipeline.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER program enables significant advances in the design and runtime management of low-power, self-sustained wearable devices, especially those implemented using flexible hybrid electronics (FHE). The novel systems studied in this project are capable of sensing, communication, and local processing, enabling artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) algorithms at the edge. The FHE technology combines the physical and cost advantages of flexible electronics with silicon technology's superior processing and storage capabilities. The primary and broadly applicable contributions of this CAREER program are summarized below.

  • It developed a comprehensive, end-to-end framework and tools for designing truly wearable devices by explicitly defining and considering physical flexibility in addition to traditional power, performance, and cost metrics.
  • It produced optimal energy harvesting and management techniques that enable self-sustained operation without relying on user maintenance effort.
  • It led to one of the first flexible hybrid electroånics prototypes on a thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) substrate for human activity recognition and remote health monitoring applications. Besides facilitating evaluation, this prototype has driven progress toward wearable devices that can understand and assist their users.
  • The novel design approaches and prototypes were evaluated in high-impact wearable applications, including human activity recognition, runtime gait analysis, and human pose estimation. These applications and corresponding open-source datasets alone led to more than research papers and several hundred citations. 

This project had a significant potential impact on flexible hybrid electronics and wearable assistive technologies. The theoretical results, flexibility-aware techniques, and the Flexible Hybrid Electronics (FHE) prototypes have started transforming lives by providing a systematic approach to designing wearable systems and arbitrarily shaped objects. Energy harvesting based on physically flexible transducers can be applied broadly to all wearable applications. Moreover, the low-power hardware accelerators designed during this project can benefit a wide range of wearable activity and health monitoring applications. Finally, the dynamic energy management techniques and home-based health monitoring applications developed in this project widely apply to low-power embedded systems.

The research performed in this project has also been tightly integrated with education. Three Ph.D., over five MS, and three undergraduate students have been trained during the project. In addition, the novel concepts studied in this project have been integrated into one graduate and one undergraduate course offered at Arizona State University and the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Pre- and post-surveys showed that students' knowledge of these topics and interest increased significantly after taking these classes. 

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Umit Y Ogras

It developed a comprehensive, end-to-end framework and tools for designing truly wearable devices by explicitly defining and considering physical flexibility in addition to traditional power, performance, and cost metrics.
It produced optimal energy harvesting and management techniques that enable self-sustained operation without relying on user maintenance effort.
It led to one of the first flexible hybrid electronics prototypes on a thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) substrate for human activity recognition and remote health monitoring applications.Besides facilitating evaluation, this prototype has driven progress toward wearable devices that can understand and assisttheir users.

The research performed in this project has also been tightly integrated with education. Three Ph.D., over five MS, and three undergraduate students have been trained during the project.
